citation.article-title: Actinomyces denticolens Dent & Williams sp. nov: a new species from the dental plaque of cattle

p.s: Description of Actinomyces denticolens sp. nov.
Actinomyces denticolens (L.n. dens, dentis tooth; L. adj. suff colens from L.v. colo dwell; L. adj. dentirolens tooth dweller)
Morphology Gram positive, non-spore forming, non-motile rods (0.7 μm x 5 μm).
Colonies on horse blood agar slightly pink when grown anaerobically, but white if grown aerobically.
Colonies circular, entire and convex, smooth.
Physiological properties Facultatively anaerobic, stimulated by carbon dioxide; catalase negative; reduces nitrate but not nitrite, hydrolyses aesculin; not haemolytic.

Ferment glucose, lactose, maltose, raffinose, salicin, sucrose; most strains ferment inositol, inulin and ribose, and some ferment amygdalin, cellobiose, glycerol, mannose, melezitose and rhamnose weakly.
Arabinose, sorbitol, trehalose and xylose are not fermented.
Cell suspensions show activities of leucine amino-peptidase, phosphoamidase, β-galactosidase and α-glucosidase; most strains also show acid phosphatase, 1-galactosidase and β-glucosidase.
Chemical composition Peptidoglycan contains glutamate, alanine, ornithine, lysine, glucosamine and muramic acid in the proportions 2:2:1:1:1:1.
The only detectable carbohydrate in purified cell walls is rhamnose.
DNA base composition 65.9-67.7 moles % G + C.
Pattern of polypeptides on SDS-PAGE is unique and allows the taxon to be distinguished from A. naeslundii.
Isolated from the dental plaque of cattle.
